title.narrative: We are able! Uganda

description.narrative: By 2025, through engagement with public authorities (formal and informal powerholders), men, women and youth with disabilities and other excluded groups, through resilient and capable local CSOs/DPOs in this fragile and conflict-affected country, are successfully influencing laws, policies, practices and norms for improved food security for all.

The We are able! program targets people (including women, men, and youth) with a disability, while, as spin-off, the program will also create opportunities for other excluded groups,3 such as vulnerable women, persons affected by leprosy, youth in general, excluded ethnic groups, internally displaced persons (IDPs) and refugees, as much as possible or necessary in the specific context. Intersectional traits often make people particularly vulnerable. Refugees with disabilities or disabled women and men of particular ethnic backgrounds often face the most severe forms of food insecurity. We are able! identifies and targets groups and individuals with particular vulnerabilities while creating synergies that allow others to benefit as well.

The activities in Uganda are part of the We are able! program in DR Congo, Burundi, Ethiopia, South Sudan, Sudan and Uganda. Food security in these countries is low. People with disabilities (PWDs) are even more likely to live in food insecure households. We are able! wants to see PWDs improving their right to food and food security by creating an enabling environment for right-to-food action at grassroots level. While PWDs are the core target group of the We are able! program, we create benefits for other excluded groups like vulnerable women, youth in general, marginalised ethnic groups and internally displaced persons (IDPs), as applicable per context.

title.narrative: SCS3 # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage Methodological notes
# of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1)ARUA District Union of persons with disabilities, Epilepsy Support Association Arua & District Association of the Blind: The organisations have successfully lobbied for the design and construction of accessible public buildings for persons with disabilities. 2) Nwoya District Association for the Blind: Visited and lobbied district authorities, including district community development officer, chief administrative officer, district councilors for the formation of Nwoya Association for the Blind. They are currently lobbying for office space, and the establishment of sub-county Centres for Disability 3) Nwoya District Girls and women with disabilities Association & - Disability Council for Nwoya District: Managed to increase district grant for persons with disabilities through lobbying. The annual disabilities grant was raised from Ugx. 500,000 to Ugx. 1,500,000 per year. 4) Yumbe District Union of persons with disabilities (YUDUPED), Sign Health Uganda, Humanity and inclusion & Yumbe District Association of the Blind Meetings with DEO and protocol head on inclusive education. Have a DEO in-charge of special needs education for persons with disabilities and ensure implementation of the ‘Inclusive education policy’. 5) Yumbe District Union of persons with disabilities (YUDUPED), Sign Health Uganda, Humanity and inclusion & Yumbe District Association of the Blind: 2) Meetings and discussions on accessibility of buildings in public places by persons with disabilities. Ramps have been put now in most public buildings like health centres, government office buildings and schools. 6) Yumbe District Union of persons with disabilities (YUDUPED), Sign Health Uganda, Humanity and inclusion & Yumbe District Association of the Blind: Have sign language interpreters recruited to communicate with persons with hearing impairment in all public gatherings, and in health facilities, schools and police stations. 7) Yumbe District Union of persons with disabilities (YUDUPED), Sign Health Uganda, Humanity and inclusion & Yumbe District Association of the Blind: Adjustable beds now being provided in health facilities, and plans are underway to have health workers trained on basic sign language skills to enable them provide services to PWDs. 8) Nwoya Disabled Persons Union (NDPU) Engagement with public authorities resulted in the Council to agree to train 3 District Local Government civil workers on sign language interpretation to improve the flow of information to and from persons with disabilities, persons with hearing impairments in particular.

title.narrative: # of times that CSOs succeed in creating space for CSO demands and positions through agenda setting, influencing the debate and/or creating space to engage at national and international level

comment.narrative: No examples found of CSOs that succeeded in creating space

title.narrative: SCS2 # of laws, policies blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement.
# of by-laws blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: District Disability Council for Madi Okollo 1) Enabling persons with disabilities, especially those with physical disabilities to access public buildings and places through consultations and lobbying with the District Engineer and Chief Administrative Officer, assisted by District Community Development Office. This was successfully lobbied for and all district headquarters buildings (which are relatively new) and more under construction – now have ramps for wheelchairs.

comment.narrative: No cases of blocked, adopted or improved international agreements were found

title.narrative: # of private sector company policies blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: No cases of blocked, adopted or improved private sector company policies were found.

title.narrative: # of laws blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: Omoro Women and Girls with Disability Association 1) Law/policy is worked on by the women councillors for persons with disabilities aiming to eliminate discrimination of and negative perception about women and girls with disabilities as being useless persons through training of all stakeholders on GBV and advocating for imposing serious punishments on culprits. (in progress)

title.narrative: # of governmental policies blocked, adopted, improved for sustainable and inclusive development as a result of CSO engagement

comment.narrative: Yumbe District Union of persons with disabilities (YUDUPED), Sign Health Uganda, Humanity and inclusion & Yumbe District Association of the Blind 1) Improvement in the implementation of the equal opportunity policy through discussions and engagements with local authority. As a result at the district, there is now a senior community development officer specially in-charge of persons with disabilities issues. In the recruitment of district staffs there are slots given specifically for persons with disabilities and persons with disabilities participate fully in elections where they also elect their representatives at all levels. 2) Improvement in the implementation of the inclusive education policy through discussions and engagements with local authority. Now a District Education Officer (DEO) in-charge of special needs education who specifically handles issues of persons with disabilities education is recruited; improvements in infrastructures like putting ramps to allow easy accessibility of school buildings by students with disabilities has been done; learning aids/equipment like braillie have been acquired. These two cases could also be counted under SCS011, but since the WeAreAble consortium does not report under this indicator, these cases are categorized here.

title.narrative: SCS4 # of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency
# of advocacy initiatives carried out by CSOs, for, by or with their membership/constituency at sub-national level

comment.narrative: 1) Nwoya Disabled Persons Union (NDPU): Community training on equality, inclusion and right of work. Training of the communities on the issue of equal treatment. 2) Nwoya Disabled Persons Union (NDPU): Communities and parents of children with disabilities have been sensitized on the value of, and the right to education for children with disability. 3) Nwoya Disabled Persons Union (NDPU): Equal access, control or ownership of land. In partnership with ZOA some persons with disabilities have been able access, control or have ownership of land. 4) ARUA District Union of persons with disabilities, Epilepsy Support Association Arua & District Association of the Blind: Engaging District Council to have disability representatives in other sector committees e.g. Agriculture, Education, to influence debate. 5) ARUA District Union of persons with disabilities, Epilepsy Support Association Arua & District Association of the Blind Advocating for self-empowerment of persons with disabilities, encouraging children with disabilities to work and get own resources from within for self-support and for their children to go to school. 6) ARUA District Union of persons with disabilities, Epilepsy Support Association Arua & District Association of the Blind: Sensitizing the general population and persons with disabilities on their rights. 7) Nwoya District Girls and women with disabilities Association & - Disability Council for Nwoya District: Formation of District Disability Councils to advocate for persons with disabilities. 8) Nwoya District Girls and women with disabilities Association & - Disability Council for Nwoya District: Mobilizing local community including community leaders and, training and sensitizing them on equal rights for disabled women and girls to control, manage and use properties. 9) Omoro Women and Girls with Disability Association Equal rights for women and girls with disabilities to have access to or own land and property, be equally involved in decision making related to family land and property issues. 10) Yumbe District Union of persons with disabilities (YUDUPED), Sign Health Uganda, Humanity and inclusion & Yumbe District Association of the Blind: Collaboration with other CSOs to advocate for inclusion of persons with disabilities in the district taskforce for Covid-19 to ensure that communication related to Covid-19 including SOPs, lockdown and curfew information reach PWDs timely and in appropriate way.
